definition:
The [*level curves*]{} (in German [*Niveaukurve*]{}, in French [*ligne
de niveau*]{}) of a surface $$\begin{aligned}
z \;=\; f(x,\,y)\end{aligned}$$ in $\mathbb{R}^3$ are the intersection
curves of the surface and the planes $z = \,\mathrm{constant}$. Thus the
projections of the level curves on the $xy$-plane have equations of the
form $$\begin{aligned}
f(x,\,y) \;=\; c\end{aligned}$$ where $c$ is a constant.\
For example, the level curves of the $z = xy$ are the rectangular
hyperbolas $xy = c$ (cf. ).\
The gradient $f'_x(x,\,y)\,\vec{i}\!+\!f'_y(x,\,y)\,\vec{j}$ of the
function $f$ in any point of the surface (1) is perpendicular to the
level curve (2), since the slope of the gradient is
$\displaystyle\frac{f'_y}{f'_x}$ and the slope of the level curve is
$\displaystyle-\frac{f'_x}{f'_y}$, whence the slopes are opposite
inverses.\
Analogically one can define the [*level surfaces*]{} (or [*contour
surfaces*]{}) $$\begin{aligned}
F(x,\,y,\,z) \;=\; c\end{aligned}$$ for a function $F$ of three
variables $x$, $y$, $z$. The gradient of $F$ in a point $(x,\,y,\,z)$ is
parallel to the surface normal of the level surface passing through this
point.
